incident_updates.body: We've rolled back some infrastructure changes that may have allowed the registry to leak connections. Registry errors have returned to normal levels, and deploys are functioning properly in all regions.
The registry is rejecting connections from some hosts in some regions. We're restarting processes, which seems to be helping reduce the error rate.
We are investigating an increased rate of image pull failures in a handful of regions. These are interfering with some customer deploys, and show as a failed VM in `fly status`.
Metrics issues have been resolved.
We've increased the limits for metrics ingestion across the impacted cluster and are monitoring recovery.
Currently investigating problems with metrics ingestion. It looks like querying metrics still works.
This incident has been resolved.
We have noticed consistently high demand in the SJC region and are provisioning additional capacity.

incidents.name: Some apps unreachable in the EWR region

incident_updates.body: This incident was resolved.

affected_components.name: Application Hosting - EWR - Secaucus, New Jersey (US)

incident_updates.body: We're looking into reports of apps being unreachable in EWR.

affected_components.name: Application Hosting - EWR - Secaucus, New Jersey (US)

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We have rolled out upgrades to our Nomad cluster which have resolved the issue with deployments for Apps V1. We are monitoring for further issues.
We have identified an issue with our Nomad cluster and are continuing with repair work.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are investigating an issue with our Nomad cluster that causes deployments to fail.
This incident has been resolved.
We've resolved the issue with our Nomad cluster and are monitoring the situation.
We're working to mitigate the issue with our Nomad cluster.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We're still investigating this issue.
We are investigating an issue with our Nomad cluster that causes deployments to fail. We have disabled new Nomad deployments for now. Apps that are currently running aren't impacted.
This incident has been resolved.
We have re-enabled deployments for Apps V1 in CDG and are monitoring for further issues.
We are continuing to work on enabling deployments for Apps V1 in CDG.
We have identified the affected servers and are enabling deployments.

We are investigating residual issues in some regions following the blocked Apps V1 deployments.

At this time we believe only CDG is affected.
This incident has been resolved.
We are monitoring the recovery of AppV1/Nomad deployments.
Vault and AppV1/Nomad deploys are recovering. We are continuing with additional repair work.
We have isolated the AppsV1 deployment problems to failures interacting with Vault and are working to mitigate further issues.

AppsV1/Nomad deploys have been re-enabled.

We continue to investigate a subset of customer apps that remain unable to schedule deploys.

We have identified an issue that resulted in selected AppsV1 deployments failing to be properly scheduled.

Deployments of AppsV1 continue to be blocked while we isolate the issue.
Deploys and application scaling have been paused while we continue to work to resolve the issue.
Issues with Routing and DNS have been mitigated. Deploys for AppsV1 continue to be impacted.

We are investigating failure reports of DNS and proxy routing. Deploys are impacted as well.

Routing to Machines is not believed to be impacted.

incidents.name: Increased WebSockets errors in FRA, IAD, EWR and YUL

incident_updates.body: A regression in our proxy code caused an increase in WebSocket errors in several regions. Apps experiencing these issues showed variants of "Message too long (error 90)" in their application logs.
The registry is fully restored.
We are still not seeing any new issues reported and are planning to re-deploy the registry again to ensure all issues from earlier have been resolved.
The registry has been recovered from a previous version and we've re-enabled deploys as we continue to monitor for new issues.
Users may also see an increase in error rates when attempting to create or update machines using the API.
We've identified the issue and are working to rollback the most recent deploy of the registry.
We're seeing an increased number of errors or timeouts when pushing images to registry.fly.io during deploys.

incidents.name: Packet loss from Singapore to multiple regions

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We are working to route around multiple fiber cuts that are currently affecting singapore.
We're working with our providers to bypass a bad route.
Causing intermittent issues deploying to SIN.
This incident has been resolved.
Our Consul cluster is now stable again. We've re-enabled Nomad deployments and are monitoring for any further issues.
The Consul cluster rebuild is nearly completed and we are working to restore service.
The Consul cluster rebuild is nearly completed and we are working to restore service.

We are working to build a new Consul cluster with 10x the RAM. We aren't yet sure, but believe a routine DNS change might have created a thundering herd problem causing Consul servers to immediately increase RAM usage by 500%. This is not ideal.
We're still working on recovering our Consul cluster.
Our Consul cluster is experiencing an outage. This impacts queries to our API, including creating and modifying apps, as well as incoming network requests for recently deployed apps.

incidents.name: CDG host did not restart cleanly, preventing instances with volumes to start

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
CDG instances with volumes are now back.
We are continuing to work on a fix for this issue.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
This incident has been resolved.
We currently have deploys enabled while we monitor Nomad's backlog.
We've disabled deploys again to allow nomad to catch up on its Job Evalutations.
Nomad is working through a backlog of job evaluations, this is slowing deploys to the point where they're failing in many cases.
We've restored our Nomad server cluster (now with 10x the RAM) and are re-enabling deploy functionality.

We are working to restore the Nomad server cluster. Our current priority is restoring Nomad without disrupting running applications. There is a chance this is unsuccessful, and applications reboot unexpectedly when we get Nomad back online.

We have temporarily disabled Apps V1 deploys.

Our Apps V1 platform is currently operating in a severely degraded state. Apps that are already running will stay running, but any changes to VM state will fail, including deploys. This is a result of capacity issues in our underlying nomad cluster. An attempt to grow our cluster has left it in a bad state which we are working to correct.

Our API is also being impacted and will be intermittently available until the Apps V1 platform is restored.

incidents.name: Deployment monitoring and app status have stale data

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We are continuing to monitor for any further issues.
Things are better but deploys / release commands are still slower than they should be. Instance statuses are also delayed a bit as our state is synchronizing.
We've upped the memory allocated for that app so it doesn't crash anymore and it seems a lot more stable now.

A synchronization service we are running crashing from time to time causing deployment monitoring to fail at times and app status to show erroneous information about instances.

The cause of the crash has not yet been determined.

incidents.name: Apps V1 Instances are sometimes, wrongly, being stopped without user intervention

incident_updates.body: Bigger servers in place, Nomad is running healthily.
We are provisioning far bigger servers to handle the increased workload our Nomad cluster has seen these past months.
Removing the server from the cluster seems to have helped with this issue temporarily.
Our nomad cluster has consistency issues right now due to one of the servers at the limits of its resources. This seems to have an effect on apps V1.

incidents.name: Delayed state updates: expect more proxy retries for instances of new deployments

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
State is a lot more consistent now and most problems should be resolved. Working on final consistency fixes.
We are now restoring missing state information from every server, 1 by 1.
We are aware some apps are still experiencing issues and are continuing work to fix state inconsistencies causing proxy timeouts.
There are still some issues with older deployments, we are still cleaning up the state.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are continuing to work on a fix for this issue.
Apps v1 deploys have been disabled as we're working on restoring a working state.
We're rolling back this update
An ongoing upgrade is causing delayed app instances state propagation

We are aware of the issue and are working on a fix

incident_updates.body: This is now resolved
This issue has been resolved by our upstream provider and we are monitoring the situation.
One of our upstream transit providers is experiencing issues in the JNB region. We are working with them to resolve this.

We've identified the underlying problem impacting our vault cluster and are working to mitigate further impact to users.

incidents.name: Machine API Unavailable on some hosts/regions.

We've resolved the issue on all affected hosts and are monitoring for additional errors.
We're currently working to restore the API on affected hosts/regions.

incident_updates.body: This issue has been resolved.
Network connectivity has been restored and we are monitoring the situation.
This outage has been caused by some emergency unscheduled maintenance in the datacenter. We currently expect service to be resumed in the next 30 minutes.
We are currently experiencing connectivity issues in the SCL region. We are working with our upstream providers to resolve this.
Capacity has been added to YUL

We are at capacity in YUL. This means your deployments might fail if the only region you have setup for your app is YUL. YYZ is also nearing capacity so we'd advise adding other nearby regions like IAD or EWR while we add more capacity in Montreal.

We are investigating an issue affecting app deployments with release commands, where a configured release command will run but the rest of the deployment won't continue.
To workaround the issue, remove/comment out the release_command in your app config.

The proxy has returned to stable operation at this point. Our metrics indicate intermittent routing errors occurring between 18:10-18:45 UTC.
We have identified a routing issue in our edge proxy caused by a recent configuration update and are working on deploying a fix.

Application hosts in SEA experienced a 17-minute network interruption from 08:49 - 09:06 UTC (00:49-01:06 PST local time), due to a temporary network issue at our datacenter provider.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
Issues with multiple pacific ocean underwater cables providing connectivity to / from SIN with certain providers.

incidents.name: Creating or listing checks for Postgres clusters return errors

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
A change in health checks timestamp precision caused problems with the machines API. A fix is being deployed.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.

At 23:42 UTC on 2023-01-20 firewall rules were deployed that dropped traffic to fly-proxy. We quickly reverted the change, but the rollback encountered an issue. The rollback completed successfully around 23:59 UTC and operations resumed as usual.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are currently experiencing an outage with fly-proxy. Connections to Fly.io apps will receive connection refused errors. We're actively investigating.
Workaround identified. See forum post.

We tracked the source of this problem to an upgrade of Buildkit on Github Actions. See this community post for a workaround: https://community.fly.io/t/deploying-to-fly-via-github-action-failing/10171/19?u=jsierles
Some users are currently experiencing 'image not found' errors when using Github Actions to deploy.
This incident has been resolved.
All apps are back up and running on the affected host.

We're investigating a failure of a single application host in FRA. Most apps have been rerouted to other hosts in the region, but apps with mounted volumes on the affected host will remain unavailable as we work on recovery.
This incident has been resolved.
The issue has been identified at the impacted datacenter and a fix is being implemented.
There is an issue impacting network stability on a number of application hosts in the IAD region.

We investigated intermittent container-image issues and deployment failures in SIN, and tracked down the issue to a congested public Internet route from SIN to AWS us-east-1 impacting container image pull performance. Our monitoring shows this network congestion occurring daily from Jan 10-12, roughly between 02:00-18:00 UTC.

We deployed a change to our container registry to route around this network congestion, so the deployment issues should now be resolved moving forward.
This incident has been resolved.
We've added more resources to IAD and deployments are no longer being delayed.
We're investigating delayed deployments in the IAD (Ashburn, Virginia US) region. This region is at full capacity and we're working on adding more resources.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We're investigating slow response times across our platform APIs.

incident_updates.body: IPv6 addresses are working properly and certificate issuance is back to normal.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
We are investigating routing issues for new apps. These are preventing access over IPv6 and interfering with certificate generation.

incidents.name: Deployments may take 10-15min in fra region

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

We're experiencing high utilization in the fra (Frankfurt) region. Deployments and scale up events in the region may take 10-15min, or more in some cases, to complete. This does not impact running apps; they will continue to work as expected.

flyctl may detach during deployments to instances in Frankfurt. The deployments will continue to completion. Use `fly status` or the "Monitoring" tab in the dashboard to track progress.

Deployments to the fra region require a paid plan (Launch, Scale, Enterprise, or a legacy paid plan). Existing apps and allocs running in fra are not affected. The limitation affects new apps, volumes, and changes to scale. This is a temporary restriction.

Maintenance is complete.

We are increasing database capacity. This requires a failover between cluster nodes. There may be a small outage while the failover happens that will result in some API calls failing. This will not impact running apps.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are currently investigating issues in deploying applications
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
DNSimple has identified the issue and things seem to be improving.

You can workaround this DNS issue if you own your own domain. Run `fly ips list` to see the IPs assigned to your app, then create an A record pointing to the IPv4 address, and an AAAA record pointed to the IPv6 address. Then `fly certs add <yourhostname>`.
Name resolution is failing for fly.dev (and other DNSimple hosted domains).
